description: From Latin deflecto, from de- (“away”) + flecto (“to bend”).

verbs.description: deflect (third-person singular simple present deflects, present participle deflecting, simple past and past participle deflected)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (something) deviate from its original path.
(transitive, ball games) To touch the ball, often unwittingly, after a shot or a sharp pass, thereby making it unpredictable for the other players.
examples: The defender deflected the cross into his own net.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deviate from its original path.
(transitive, figuratively) To avoid addressing (questions, criticism, etc.).
examples: The Prime Minister deflected some increasingly pointed questions by claiming he had an appointment.
